intro: Xiphion xiphium var. taitii, commonly known as the Taiti daffodil, is a rare and striking plant native to the island of Taiti in the French Southern and Antarctic Territories. It is a member of the Amaryllidaceae family, characterized by its showy, trumpet-shaped flowers that are typically yellow or orange in color. The plant features narrow, grass-like leaves and produces a single stem that bears a cluster of blooms. It thrives in well-drained soils and requires full sun to partial shade, making it a unique addition to specialized gardens. Due to its limited distribution and conservation status, it is considered a rare and valuable species in botanical collections.
